A car caravan demonstration is underway outside of the Bolero Flats apartments in Downtown Minneapolis. 

The caravan comes in the wake of the fatal shooting of Amir Locke by police on Wednesday, February 2.

results.raw: Amir Locke Fatally Shot by Police Executing No-Knock Warrant in Downtown Minneapolis at 1117 Marquette Ave, Minneapolis, Minnesota, 55403
results.title: Amir Locke Fatally Shot by Police Executing No-Knock Warrant in Downtown Minneapolis

-MuuVhq2JNQbgrYOS7Fg.text: Firefighters are responding to an unconfirmed report of a person shot.

-MuvJEyAQMvNBSr5oqoy.text: According to the Minnesota Department of Public Safety Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, the shooting involved a police officer. It's unclear who fired the shots and if anyone was injured.

-Mv6ZX1HNkeR0s7CTCGT.text: On Friday, February 4, Mayor Jacob Frey announced there would be a moratorium on no-knock warrants issued by the city.

nib.text:
An allegedly armed man was fatally shot by police who were executing a no-knock search warrant in a Downtown West apartment Wednesday morning, officials said.

At 6:48 a.m., MPD SWAT officers responded to the Bolero Flats apartment building at 1117 Marquette Avenue to serve a search warrant related to a homicide investigation being conducted by Saint Paul police. 

In a press briefing Wednesday afternoon, interim Chief Amelia Huffman said the officers loudly announced their presence as they entered the apartment. 

Bodycam footage released by city officials late Thursday night showed officers entering the apartment and encountering 22-year-old Amir Locke who appeared to be asleep on the couch covered in a blanket. 

Locke moved upward still covered in the blanket as officers commanded him to raise his arms. 

Within seconds of saying the commands, at least two officers began firing at Locke. 
 
Police and EMS personnel attempted to provide him with first aid before transporting him to an area hospital, where he was pronounced deceased. 

A loaded handgun was recovered from the scene. 

According to Ben Crump, the attorney representing Locke's family, Locke legally owned a firearm and that "all available information" showed Locke was not the subject of the search warrant. 

The Minnesota Department of Public Safety Bureau of Criminal Apprehension is conducting an investigation. 

On Friday, February 4, Mayor Jacob Frey announced there would be a moratorium on no-knock warrants issued by the city.
